awd_titl_txt: II-NEW: The BetaHome Network: A Multi-Home Testbed for Smart Building Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding for a new institutional Computing Research Infrastructure (CRI) project focused on residential energy research at the University of Virginia. Recent studies have demonstrated great potential for applications of embedded sensing and control in the home environment.  However, research in this area is limited by the inability to experiment beyond small scale field tests and pilot studies.  The BetaHome Network is a new residential sensing testbed that includes an array of homes with extensive and semi-permanent instrumentation of the electrical, water, and HVAC systems.  The testbed captures several dimensions of variability in homes that are not captured by one-off field tests and small pilot studies.  Additionally, and perhaps most importantly, the BetaHome Network system tracks and records the locations of occupants within the home, in relation to the energy, water, and HVAC events that are also being recorded.  This unique sensing testbed provides a complete, real-time picture of both occupancy and energy usage in the home with unprecedented detail about the internal happenings of the home.  The testbed enables several new types of studies that were heretofore impractical, including cross-sectional analytics and controlled intervention studies.  The project enables research on novel techniques for (i) occupancy and energy monitoring in homes (ii) personalized energy feedback (iii) intelligent thermostat control (iv) low-cost energy audits, and (v) intelligent fixture-driven water heating.

The research infrastructure created by this project enables research on new home monitoring and energy efficiency technologies, focusing on practical and low-cost solutions that can be readily translated to market.  For example, preliminary studies demonstrated a 28% reduction per household in the energy required for heating and cooling, at the cost of only $25 in additional sensors per home.  This project opens a new realm for residential ``living laboratories'' that enhance the infrastructure for research and education in the area of energy-efficient technologies, helping to propel the nation towards its goal of a 70% improvement in the total energy efficiency of existing buildings across the country by 2030.  New courses are being developed as a result of this infrastructure and both graduate and undergraduate researchers are involved in new research.  The project is producing a new data set of unprecedented detail that can be used as benchmarks for the energy monitoring community to enable research and inspire future generations of researchers to study science and engineering by illustrating its applied nature and potential for social benefit.

por.por_cntn:
This project created new infrastructure to advance the state of smart home research, including new software tools, datasets, and hardware designs that enable simple and cost-effective analysis of home occupancy and activity in homes. The project created a new software platform called Piloteur for reliably collecting sensor data during pilot studies in smart homes, including lighting usage, appliance usage, water fixtures, and room location of occupants. Piloteur was designed for easy, low-cost, and reliable deployment and has been made available to the public as a free download from GitHub. The project also created several new hardware designs for tracking the location of occupants in the home with room-level accuracy. These designs range in complexity from simple motion sensors to radar sensors and thermal imagers, creating a selection of hardware designs for person tracking in smart home studies. Together, these two systems enable collection of data from both smart home objects and the occupants inside of the smart homes. These systems were used in multiple studies and in the aggregate were used to collect data from over 50 homes over the course of hundreds of days. Each study contains ground truth data and as well as observations that help to answer a specific scientific question, and these data sets have been made publicly available for download on the World Wide Web. The software, hardware, and data infrastructure produced by this project is expected to enable gains in a range of related fields from home entertainment to healthcare to home energy management.

In addition to the new research infrastructure, this project has resulted in numerous other outcomes for research and education. It created  training and professional development opportunities for several new, supporting two Masters students and two PhD students. It also lead to numerous opportunities for undergraduate students to become involved in research and has resulted in two scientific publications that were co-authored by undergraduate students. The project supported 21 scientific and peer-reviewed publications, including 2 journal articles, 17 conference papers, 1 workshop paper, and 1 demo abstract. These publications have been made available to the public for download on the World Wide Web and through archival electronic libraries. In addition, the research outcomes and the research infrastructure was leveraged to help inspire future generations of researchers by presenting the results at public open houses, at conferences, in undergraduate courses, and by giving live demos of the work, illustrating the potential of applied computer science research and its tangible social benefits.
